title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring no break in service with the employer for the purpose of benefit accrual. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The period of continued participation is considered service with the employer, and earnings and forfeitures are not included in determining liabilities. In a multiemployer plan, the liability allocation is determined by the plan sponsor or the last employer before the qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Continued participation extends until the participant reaches normal retirement age, the employer stops providing the plan, or contributions are not paid. Qualified beneficiaries electing continued participation are responsible for funding plan obligations for benefits. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The plan allocates applicable contributions to beneficiaries in the same manner as for other beneficiaries. Benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions are only provided if available prior to the qualifying event. Participants are deemed to have received compensation at the rate prior to the qualifying event during continued participation. During continued participation, the qualified beneficiary's contributions are limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period, and can be made in monthly installments. Contributions cannot be required before 45 days after the initial election for continued participation. The election period begins no later than the date of the qualifying event. The election period for continued participation in the plan begins no later than the date of the qualifying event and lasts at least 90 days. Any qualified beneficiary's election includes other beneficiaries affected by the qualifying event. Certain defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees are exempt. Definitions for this section are provided. Definitions for this section include the applicable contribution, qualified beneficiary, and qualifying event. A qualifying event is any event within seven years of the participant's normal retirement age that would result in the cessation of benefit accruals for a qualified beneficiary. Certain defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees are exempt from this provision. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions that would lead to the cessation of benefit accruals for a qualified beneficiary, including termination or reduction of employment hours and the death of the participant. The Act applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996, with a special rule for defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements, not applying before the termination of agreements or January 1, 2000.
